key_insight: A hybrid 3D representation—combining a compact triangle mesh for surfaces with anisotropic 3D Gaussians for fine, volumetric detail—yields photoreal head avatars that are both memory- and runtime-efficient enough for mobile rendering.
problem_solved: How to produce photorealistic, multi-view-derived head avatars that preserve fine detail (hair, soft occlusions, view-dependent effects) while meeting tight memory, bandwidth, and real-time rendering constraints on mobile devices.
method: Hybrid representation: use a low-cost triangle mesh to model primary surface geometry (e.g., skin) and anisotropic 3D Gaussians to represent volumetric, view-dependent, and fine-detail regions.
Fit the hybrid model from multi-view images (reconstruction + optimization) and compress the result into a compact codec-like avatar.
Mobile-optimized rendering pipeline (efficient rasterization/splatting, LOD and quantization) to achieve real-time, low-memory playback while preserving photorealism.
impact: Enables deployment of high-quality, interactive head avatars on resource-constrained devices (AR/VR, telepresence, mobile apps), lowering memory and compute barriers for photoreal 3D experiences.
visual_elements: Side-by-side rendering showing decomposition: triangle mesh overlay + 3D Gaussian blobs visualized on a head model.
Pipeline diagram: multi-view images → hybrid fitting/compression → mobile-optimized renderer.
Performance chart: memory footprint and latency vs. visual quality comparing GPiCA to mesh-only and point-based baselines.
Before/after gallery: photoreal output frames rendered on mobile vs. ground-truth photos.
paper_title: Gaussian Pixel Codec Avatars: A Hybrid Representation for Efficient Rendering
paper_authors: Divam Gupta, Anuj Pahuja, Nemanja Bartolovic, Tomas Simon, Forrest Iandola
